H0.text: Vaccine is the preventative measure traditionally used to stimulate the immune system with weakened or inactive forms of microorganisms or viruses.

H1.text: Infection is the preventative measure that traditionally uses weakened or inactive forms of microorganisms or viruses to stimulate the immune system.

H2.text: Assimilation is the preventative measure that traditionally uses weakened or inactive forms of microorganisms or viruses to stimulate the immune system.

H3.text: Pathogen is the preventative measure that traditionally used weakened or inactive forms of microorganisms or viruses to stimulate the immune system.

A4.text: A vaccine typically contains an agent that resembles a disease-causing microorganism and is often made from weakened or killed forms of the microbe, its toxins, or one of its surface proteins.

A5.text: The live Mycobacterium tuberculosis vaccine developed by Calmette and Gu√©rin is not made of a contagious strain but contains a virulently modified strain called 'BCG' used to elicit an immune response to the vaccine.
